content.question: Which of the following best explains how Zionism emerged as a response to nationalism in the late nineteenth century?

choices.label: Increasing anti-Semitism convinced some European Jews that the creation of their own nation was the logical response.
Newly unified nations such as Germany extended citizenship and voting rights to Jews.
Romantic nationalists looked to the emotional bonds of religious beliefs as justification for unifying nations.
Jewish leaders were inspired by European empire-building in Asia and Africa to conquer their own territory.

content.answer: Increasing anti-Semitism convinced some European Jews that the creation of their own nation was the logical response.
